title: How to Make a Signal Flare

steps.headline: Mix together the potassium nitrate and the aluminum powder.
steps.description: Other metals will work, such as copper powder, zinc powder, potassium permanganate makes a purple flame.

steps.headline: Cook the mixture on low heat for awhile and take it off and let it cool in a bucket or something.
Add the bonding agent to the mixture and wait for awhile.
Add the mixture while it's about half done drying, put it into your cylinder tube.
steps.description: Also put in a few matches while it dries.

steps.headline: Light it up.
steps.description: Put it on the ground and have some fun.

steps.headline: Mix 1/2 cup powdered sugar and 3/4 cup potassium nitrate in a shake-able container or jar.
steps.description: Shake and turn the container to allow the material to be thoroughly mixed.

steps.headline: Light a propane camp stove in a safe, outdoor location.
steps.description: Crank the flame down to a low level. Most propane stoves will produce a 1/4-inch high flame at this level.

steps.headline: Place the flare mixture in a heavy skillet and heat it slowly.
steps.description: Stir the mixture constantly. As the flare gum heats it will take on the consistency of melted plastic or chewed gum. Once the material gets to a consistency that allows it to be rolled over in the skillet, it is done.

steps.headline: Remove the skillet from the heat and allow the mixture to cool for 30 minutes.
Shape the cooled flare material into a long, rectangular bar.
steps.description: Insert three matches -- wood-end first -- into one end of the flare. Push them in until the base of the match head is touching the material.

steps.headline: Wrap the flare in tissue paper and provide a 2-inch long paper end.
steps.description: Twist the end of the paper and put the flare in a self-seal plastic bag.

tyn: Tube (PVC, cardboard tube, anything will work really)
Potassium nitrate (there's a perchlorate that works better. Either sodium perchlorate or potassium
Bonding agent (flammable glue, or nail polish)
